I have a figure containing several axes on top of each other. Is it expected that linking their x axis through `linkxaxes!(ax1, ax2)` overrides the `xlims!` prescribed to each axes?
The following code leads to synchronized x-axes but without satisfying the `(0,0.5)` limits constraint.
```fig = Figure(resolution=(1000,800))
ax1,scat1 = scatter(fig[1,1],rand(10,2),color=:blue)
ax2,scat2 = scatter(fig[2,1],rand(10,2),color=:red)
xlims!(ax1,(0,0.5))
xlims!(ax2,(0,0.5))
linkxaxes!(ax1, ax2)
fig```
It would make more sense to me if `linkxaxes!` took `( min(ax1.xlims[1], ax2.xlims[1], max(ax1.xlims[2], ax2.xlims[2]) )`  as shared xlimits.

messages.text:
I merged some (not yet tagged) code that enables you to create a simple Legend by passing an Axis or LScene / Scene. Like in matplotlib etc. you can give plots labels, and labeled plots will be included in the Legend.

Also I'm working on a branch right now to put color and attribute cycling into Axis. Here's a short example with some random densities:
```let
    f = Figure()

    ax = f[1, 1] = Axis(f, palette = (color = cgrad(:seaborn_bright6, alpha = 0.7),))
    for i in 1:6
        density!(randn(100) .+ 2i, label = string(rand(names(AbstractPlotting))))
    end
    tightlimits!(ax, Bottom())

    f[1, 2] = Legend(f, ax)
    f
end```
and another with some lines where the color cycling is set to just black and gray, so linestyles show up as well
```let
    f = Figure()

    f[1, 1] = Axis(f, palette = (color = [:black, :gray50],))
    for i in 1:5
        lines!(cumsum(randn(100)), label = "$i", linewidth = 2)
    end
    f[1, 2] = Legend(f, current_axis())

    f
end```
